title: 104_s1306
content: The "Tribal Government Tax-Exempt Bond Authority Amendments Act of 1995" allows Indian tribal governments to issue tax-exempt bonds with modifications to their authority. The "Tribal Government Tax-Exempt Bond Authority Amendments Act of 1995" allows Indian tribal governments to issue tax-exempt bonds with specific requirements related to the use of proceeds and treatment of private activity bonds. The "Tribal Government Tax-Exempt Bond Authority Amendments Act of 1995" allows Indian tribal governments to issue tax-exempt bonds with specific ownership and employment restrictions for projects exceeding $500,000 in net proceeds. The "Tribal Government Tax-Exempt Bond Authority Amendments Act of 1995" requires that for each $100,000 of net proceeds from the bond issue, at least one employee at the financed facilities must be an enrolled member of an Indian tribe or the spouse of an enrolled member. The Act defines Indian tribe and Indian reservation for the purpose of this requirement. The term 'reservation' is defined in the Indian Financing Act of 1974 and the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. 'In close proximity to' means within 1 mile for reservations in metropolitan areas and within 15 miles for reservations in nonmetropolitan areas. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include an exception for bonds issued by Indian tribal governments, stating that such bonds are not exempt unless federally guaranteed. SEC. 3. EXEMPTION FROM REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to include Indian tribal governments as exempt from registration requirements. SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments apply to obligations issued after the enactment date of this Act.
